beats.reasoning: This is the first beat of an intro, which should start very subtly to build tension. According to the rules, intro sections use cool, low‑intensity washes and avoid aggressive motion or VFX. To give breathing room and follow the 60‑70% sync guideline, this beat remains empty.
Intro section with low energy and bass dominance; following the 60‑70 % sync rule and the intro buildup strategy, this beat is kept silent to allow gradual tension development.

Beat 3 of the intro has medium bass energy but no high‑energy build‑up; it’s early in the track so we keep the lighting minimal to allow tension to grow. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro guideline of subtle, cool washes, this beat is left empty for breathing room.

At 1% of the track this beat is part of the intro; the energy is only medium and the arrangement is still building tension. To follow the 60‑70% sync rule while keeping the start subtle, this beat is left empty for breathing room and gradual build‑up.

At the very start of the track (~1% of the song) the intro is meant to be subtle and build tension. The energy is medium but the dominant band is bass with low brightness, so a full light effect would break the calm atmosphere. Keeping this beat empty provides breathing room and follows the 60‑70% sync rule for early sections.

Beat 6 falls in the early intro where the track is still building tension; medium energy but no high‑energy drop or key lyric moment. To maintain a subtle, cool wash and avoid over‑lighting the calm section, we keep this beat empty for breathing room in line with the 60‑70% sync rule.

At 2% of the track, the intro is still building tension. The beat has medium energy but the high band is not yet driving a full drop, so a subtle wash is preferable. Following the 60‑70 % sync rule and the intro guidelines, this beat remains breathing room to let the lighting build naturally.

Beat 8/287 falls in the introductory section (~2% of the track) where the energy is medium but the arrangement is still building tension. Following the 60‑70% sync rule and the intro guidelines, we leave this beat empty to allow a subtle buildup without overwhelming the vocal line.

Beat 9 is in the intro with medium bass energy; a subtle motion keeps the build without overpowering. A single moving head in a gentle circle rotation with a static cool color and spectrum‑based intensity gives tension and gradual warmth.

At beat 10 the track is still in the intro, only medium energy and a gentle build. To avoid over‑lighting and give the audience breathing room, this beat is left empty, following the 60–70% sync rule and the intro‑stage‑lighting convention of minimal effects.

In the early intro (≈3% of the track) we keep the lighting subtle and build tension. With medium energy but still calm, a gentle wave on a single moving head provides slight motion without overwhelming the vocals, aligning with the 60‑70% sync rule and intro conventions.

Beat 12 sits early in the intro, medium bass energy and vocals are present. A subtle moving head with a gentle wave motion and a cool static color supports the vocal line while building tension, without the flash of a drop or VFX.

At this early intro point (beat 13/287, ~4% of the track) the energy is medium but the section is still building tension; professional practice calls for subtle, gentle light to avoid overwhelming the vocals. To maintain breathing room and gradual build‑up, this beat remains off, following the 60–70% sync rule and keeping the intro understated.

Beat 14/287 is early in the intro (~5% of the song) with medium bass energy and no lyric change. To build tension subtly we use a single moving head with a static cool color wash, keeping motion off to avoid strobe or harsh motion while providing a low‑intensity wash that supports the vocals without overwhelming them.

Beat 15 is in the intro/early verse where energy is medium but not yet building to a drop; we use a gentle wave motion on a single head to hint motion without overwhelming. A static warm wash supports the vocals while a ping‑pong intensity adds subtle breathing, following the 60‑70% sync rule and keeping the intro restrained.

At ~5% of the track, this is the intro section where we want a gentle build. The beat has medium bass energy and lyrics, so a subtle rotating single light with a static cool color and mild intensity ping‑pong keeps the mood low but moving, following the 60‑70% sync rule and avoiding over‑dramatic effects early on.

Beat 17 is still in the intro phase (~6% of the song), so the lighting should remain subtle and cool. A single light with a gentle Wave motion and a low‑intensity, static cool colour supports the bass‑dominant, medium‑energy line without overwhelming the vocals.

Beat 18 sits in the early intro, so we keep the lighting subtle yet dynamic. A single moving head with a gentle Wave motion and a cool static color supports the high‑band line without overstaging the build. No VFX or strobe are used to preserve the intro’s calm tension.

Beat 19 falls in the intro where the energy is medium but the section is still building tension. A subtle single‑head wave keeps the feel calm and supports the vocals without overwhelming the mood, following the intro guidelines of cool colors and gradual buildup.

At 7% of the track this is still early intro; we keep the lighting subtle, using a single moving head to build tension without overpowering the calm vocals. A slow rotate with a cool static blue and gentle intensity wave adds motion while respecting the intro’s restrained energy.

Beat 21 falls in the early intro (~7%) where the song is still building tension. Professional convention calls for a dark, subtle wash with minimal motion, so this beat is best left as breathing room to let the intro develop before more intense effects arrive.

Beat 22/287 falls in the intro; medium bass energy suggests a gentle wave motion to support the low end while keeping the atmosphere calm. A single moving head with a Wave effect and a subtle static cool color provides a subtle build without overwhelming the early section.

At ~8% of the track this is still in the intro. The energy is medium but the section is meant to build tension with subtle, cool colors and no strobe or VFX. Following the 60‑70% sync rule, this beat provides a breathing room, so no lighting effect is triggered.
